docs.title: Beremiz Documentation
docs.text:
Beremiz is a fun, experimental language based on the stack-based principles of Porth, created by Alexey Kutepov. While Beremiz is designed to be playful and educational, it's not intended for serious programming. Its performance is limited because it runs on top of Lua, making it relatively slow.

The name Beremiz is inspired by the character Beremiz Samir, known as "The Man Who Counted." He was created by Júlio César de Mello e Souza, a Brazilian teacher and writer better known as Malba Tahan.

A simple "Hello, World!" in Beremiz:

"Hello, World!" show

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Ensure you have Lua installed on your system. You can download it from the official Lua website.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Clone this repository locally:

git clone https://github.com/AdaiasMagdiel/beremiz.git
cd beremiz

docs.title: Running Beremiz Code
docs.text:
There are two ways to run Beremiz code:

  • Using the REPL: 

    lua main.lua

  • Passing a file: 

    lua main.lua [file]

docs.title: Example Files
docs.text:
You can find several example files in the examples folder to help you get started. Here are some key examples:

  • Factorial: A program that calculates the factorial of a number.
  • Pythagorean Theorem: Demonstrates the calculation of the hypotenuse in a right-angled triangle using the Pythagorean theorem.
  • Quadratic Equation: Solves quadratic equations and finds their roots.

docs.title: Running Tests
docs.text:
This project uses Leste, an elegant testing framework for Lua developed by me. Ensure that Leste is installed and run the tests with:

leste -vx

docs.title: Arithmetic and Comparison Operations
docs.text: This section covers a variety of arithmetic and comparison operations that are intrinsic to the language for stack manipulation.

docs.title: Arithmetic Operations
docs.text:
The available arithmetic operators are as follows:

  • +: Adds the top two items on the stack.
  • -: Subtracts the top item from the second top item on the stack.
  • *: Multiplies the top two items on the stack.
  • /: Divides the second top item by the top item on the stack.
  • %: Computes the remainder of the division of the second top item by the top item on the stack.
  • **: Raises the second top item to the power of the top item on the stack.

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
5 3  + show   # Result: 8
10 4  - show   # Result: 6
 2 3  * show   # Result: 6
10 2  / show   # Result: 5.0
10 3  % show   # Result: 1
 2 3 ** show   # Result: 8.0  (2 raised to the power of 3)

docs.title: Comparison Operations
docs.text:
The available comparison operators are as follows:

  • >: Checks if the second top item is greater than the top item on the stack.
  • =: Checks if the top two items on the stack are equal and pushes a boolean result onto the stack.
  • !=: Checks if the top two items on the stack are different and pushes a boolean result onto the stack.

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
5  3  > show   # Result: true
 2  3  > show   # Result: false
10 10  = show   # Result: true
10  5  = show   # Result: false
10 10 != show   # Result: false
10  5 != show   # Result: true

docs.title: Comments
docs.text: Comments in Beremiz serve to annotate code and provide additional information without affecting the program's execution.

docs.title: Single Line Comments
docs.text:
Single line comments can be inserted using the # character. They will be ignored by the interpreter.

Example:

# This is a single line comment

docs.title: Multi-line Comments
docs.text:
Multi-line comments can be inserted between #[ and ]#.

Example:

#[
This is a multi-line comment.
It can span multiple lines.
]#

docs.title: Conditional Execution
docs.text: Conditional execution allows you to execute code based on certain conditions using the if, and, and or keywords. The and and or operators can also be used within while loops.

docs.title: Truth Table for and
docs.text:
The and operator executes the block if both conditions are true.

if true true and do
  "true and true" show
end

if true false and do
  "true and false" show
end

if true nil and do
  "true and nil" show
end

if false true and do
  "false and true" show
end

if false false and do
  "false and false" show
end

if false nil and do
  "false and nil" show
end

if nil true and do
  "nil and true" show
end

if nil false and do
  "nil and false" show
end

if nil nil and do
  "nil and nil" show
end

docs.title: Truth Table for or
docs.text:
The or operator executes the block if at least one of the conditions is true.

if true true or do
  "true or true" show
end

if true false or do
  "true or false" show
end

if true nil or do
  "true or nil" show
end

if false true or do
  "false or true" show
end

if false false or do
  "false or false" show
end

if false nil or do
  "false or nil" show
end

if nil true or do
  "nil or true" show
end

if nil false or do
  "nil or false" show
end

if nil nil or do
  "nil or nil" show
end

docs.title: Control Structures
docs.text: In Beremiz, control structures such as while loops and if-else conditional structures enable you to manage the flow of execution within your code.

docs.title: While Loops
docs.text:
The while loop executes a set of statements repeatedly as long as a condition is true or not nil.

Example:

# Print all numbers between 0 and 10.

10   # Push 10 onto the stack

while dup 0 > do
    dup show
    1 -
end

docs.title: Break Statement
docs.text:
The break keyword is used to immediately exit a while loop, regardless of the loop's condition.

Example:

# Print numbers from 10 to 6, then exit the loop

10   # Push 10 onto the stack

while dup 0 > do
    if dup 5 = do
        break       # Exit the loop if the number is 5
    end

    dup show

    1 -
end

docs.title: Continue Statement
docs.text:
The continue keyword is used to skip the current iteration of a while loop and proceed to the next iteration.

Example:

# Print numbers from 10 to 1, but skip 5

10   # Push 10 onto the stack

while dup 0 > do
    if dup 5 = do
        1 -        # Decrement to avoid an infinite loop
        continue   # Skip the rest of the loop when the number is 5
    end

    dup show

    1 -
end

docs.title: If-Else Conditional Structures
docs.text:
The if-else structure allows conditional execution of code blocks based on specified conditions.

Example:

1 1 +        # Add 1 to 1 and push the result onto the stack

if 2 = do    # Check if the result (on the stack) is equal to 2
    "Equal" show
else
    "Not equal" show
end

docs.title: Tables
docs.text:
Tables can be created using square brackets [] to delimit elements, separated by commas ,. Tables can contain elements of different types.

Example:

[1, 2, 3, "avocado", "banana", "cashew", true, false, nil] show

This will create a table with integers, strings, booleans, and nil values. The show keyword will display the table and remove it from the stack.

Tables are useful for storing collections of data and can be manipulated using various stack operations.

docs.title: Displaying Data
docs.text: In Beremiz, you can display data in various formats using the show keyword and string interpolation.

docs.title: Showing Last Stack Element
docs.text:
The keyword show removes and displays the last element of the stack.

Example:

1 2 3  # Stack: [1, 2, 3]
show   # Output: 3 -> Stack: [1, 2]

docs.title: String Interpolation
docs.text:
String interpolation allows you to create formatted strings by consuming elements from the stack.

  • Use $0, $1, etc., within a string to refer to the elements of the stack.
  • $0 refers to the top element of the stack, $1 refers to the second element, and so on.
  • String interpolations consume the referenced stack elements in the process.

Example:

7 42                        # Stack: [7, 42]
"Num1: $1, Num2: $0" show   # Output: "Num1: 7, Num2: 42" -> Stack: []

If you try to consume more elements than are present in the stack, an error is raised. You can also escape the $n using \$n.

Example:

"Magdiel"
"Name: $0 | Escaping: \$1" show   # Output: "Name: Magdiel | Escaping: $1"

docs.title: Including Files
docs.text: In Beremiz, the include keyword allows you to import code from other files. This feature is particularly useful for organizing and reusing code across multiple files, promoting modularity and maintainability.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
You can include files using the include keyword followed by the path to the file you want to include.

Example:

include "path/to/file.brz"

Beremiz first searches for the specified file in the directory where the code is being executed. If the file is not found there, it then looks in the language's includes directory, where standard files like std.brz are located.

docs.title: Stack Operations
docs.text: Beremiz provides various operations for manipulating the stack, allowing you to efficiently manage data during program execution.

docs.title: Basic Operations
docs.text:
• over: Duplicates the second item from the top of the stack.

    Example:

    1 2   # Stack: [1, 2]
over  # Stack: [1, 2, 1]

  • dup: Duplicates the top item of the stack.

    Example:

    3 4   # Stack: [3, 4]
dup   # Stack: [3, 4, 4]

  • drop: Removes the top item from the stack.

    Example:

    1 2   # Stack: [1, 2]
drop  # Stack: [1]

  • swap: Swaps the top two items on the stack.

    Example:

    1 2   # Stack: [1, 2]
swap  # Stack: [2, 1]

  • nil: Inserts a null value into the stack.

    Example:

    1 2   # Stack: [1, 2]
nil   # Stack: [1, 2, nil]

  • dumpstack: Dumps the current stack trace for debugging purposes. This operation doesn't consume the stack.

    Example:

    1 2
dumpstack   # Output: [STACK]:
            #             NUMBER: 1 (number)
            #             NUMBER: 2 (number)
swap

dumpstack   # Output: [STACK]:
            #             NUMBER: 2 (number)
            #             NUMBER: 1 (number)

  • exit: Exits the program with an status code and a optional message.

    Example:

    # Simple exit with status 0
0 exit

# Exit with a status and message
1 "Error: File not found" exit

docs.title: Defining Variables, Constants, and Functions
docs.text: In Beremiz, defining variables, constants, and functions can significantly enhance the readability and maintainability of your code. This section explains how to define and use these elements.

docs.title: Defining Variables
docs.text: Variables in Beremiz are defined and redefined using the set keyword. Unlike constants, variables can be reassigned with new values at any time.

docs.title: Syntax:
docs.text: <value> <variable_name> set

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
42 magic set
magic show   # Output: 42

"don't panic!" magic set
magic show   # Output: "don't panic!"

docs.title: Defining Constants
docs.text: Constants in Beremiz are defined using the define keyword followed by the constant's name, its value, and the end keyword. Constants are immutable once set, providing a reliable way to use fixed values throughout your code.

docs.title: Syntax:
docs.text: define <constant_name> <value> end

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
define name "Magdiel" end
define age 22 end

docs.title: Usage:
docs.text:
name   # Pushes "Magdiel" onto the stack
age    # Pushes 22 onto the stack

docs.title: Defining Functions
docs.text: Functions in Beremiz are also defined using the define keyword, followed by the function's name, its body, and the end keyword. Functions allow you to encapsulate reusable logic within your code.

docs.title: Syntax:
docs.text:
define <function_name>
    <function_body>
end

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
define dupl
    2 *
end

docs.title: Usage:
docs.text: 5 dupl   # Multiplies 5 by 2 and adds the result to the stack

docs.title: Example of Using Constants and Functions
docs.text: By combining constants and functions, you can create more complex and reusable expressions. Here's an example that demonstrates how to use both constants and functions effectively:

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
define name "Magdiel" end
define half_age 11 end

define dupl
    2 *
end

name            # Pushes "Magdiel" onto the stack
half_age dupl   # Multiplies half_age by 2 and adds the result to the stack

"Hi, I'm $1 and I have $0" show   # Output: "Hi, I'm Magdiel and I have 22"

In this example: - name is a constant representing a string. - half_age is a constant representing a numerical value. - dupl is a function that doubles its input. - The expression "Hi, I'm $1 and I have $0" show uses these constants and the function to produce a formatted output.

docs.title: Differences Between define and set
docs.text:
• define: Used to create constants and functions. The value assigned cannot be changed after the initial definition.
  • set: Used to create or update variables. Variables can be reassigned with new values as needed.

docs.title: Math Module
docs.text: The math module provides methods for math manipulation.

docs.title: Available Methods:
docs.text: • toint

docs.title: toint
docs.text:
Converts a valid string value into a number.

Usage:

"value" math.toint

Example:

"10" math.toint
5 + show          # Output: 15

docs.title: String Module
docs.text: The string module provides methods for string manipulation.

docs.title: Available Methods:
docs.text:
• upper
  • lower
  • split

docs.title: upper
docs.text:
Converts the string on top of the stack to uppercase.

Usage:

"string" string.upper

Example:

"hello" string.upper show   # Output: HELLO

docs.title: lower
docs.text:
Converts the string on top of the stack to lowercase.

Usage:

"string" string.lower

Example:

"WORLD" string.lower show   # Output: world

docs.title: split
docs.text:
Splits the string on top of the stack by the specified separator and pushes the resulting substrings onto the stack in reverse order. This ensures the first part of the string is on the top of the stack. To split a string into individual characters, you can use an empty string as a separator.

Usage:

"string" "separator" string.split

Example:

"hello world example" " " string.split
# Stack after execution: ["example", "world", "hello"]

Another example:

"one,two,three" "," string.split
# Stack after execution: ["three", "two", "one"]

show   # Output: one
show   # Output: two
show   # Output: three

docs.title: Table Module
docs.text: The table module provides methods for manipulating tables in Beremiz.

docs.title: Available Methods:
docs.text:
• length
  • pop

docs.title: length
docs.text:
Returns the number of elements in the table.

Usage:

[1, 2, 3, "a", "b", "c"] table.length

Example:

[1, 2, 3, "a", "b", "c"] table.length show    # Output: 6

This method retrieves the length of the table, which represents the count of elements it contains.

docs.title: Notes:
docs.text:
• The length method is useful for determining the size of the table before performing operations that depend on the number of elements.
  • Empty tables return a length of 0.

docs.title: pop
docs.text:
Removes and returns the last element from the table.

Usage:

[1, 2, 3, "a", "b", "c"] table.pop

Example:

define list
    [1, 2, 3, "abacate", "banana", "caju", true, false, nil]
end

while list table.length 0 > do
    list table.pop show
end

In this example, the pop operation iteratively removes elements from the list until it is empty, displaying each removed element using show. ```
